column1: Maitland is a suburban city in Orange County
column2: Florida
column4: part of the Greater Orlando area. The population was 15
column5: 751 at the 2010 census. The area's history is exhibited at the Maitland Historical Museum. The city also hosts the Maitland Art Center
column6: and examples of Mayan Revival architecture and Fantasy Architecture
column7: the Maitland Telephone Museum and the William H. Waterhouse House Museum. A SunRail station is located in Maitland on Highway 17-92. The city is named for Fort Maitland.

column1: Maitland is one of the oldest incorporated suburban municipalities in central Florida. The area was previously inhabited by Timucuan Native Americans. The town was originally named for a nearby Lake
column2: which honored Captain William Seton Maitland
column3: who fought in the Second Seminole Indian War
column4: and was slain in the battle of Wahoo Swamp. A small military outpost was built in 1838 on the western shore of Lake Fumecheliga (later Lake Maitland) during the Second Seminole War. After the Civil War
column5: new residents arrived in the area. Christopher Columbus Beasley
column7: arrived at Lake Maitland in 1871. A post office opened on January 2 of the next year and operated in his home. Around this post office
column8: a small town grew. In the closing decades of the nineteenth century the area was put into extensive citrus production.

column1: Lake Maitland was incorporated as a town in 1885
column2: the third such town in Orange County to do so. In its infancy
column3: Lake Maitland was often characterized as a rural village
column4: with streets lined with large oak trees planted by early town aldermen. However
column5: the old town began to rapidly modernize as Orlando's suburban sprawl reached the town in the mid 1920s.  During this period the town grew rapidly as new houses and roads were built. In 1959
column6: Maitland was incorporated as a city.

column1: Maitland is a suburb of Orlando. The town's "historical corridor" encompasses old residences still standing and occupied in the Lake Lily-Lake Catherine area and extending through the central portion of the city. Examples of these century-old structures include "The Church of the Good Shepherd" (1883); "William H. Waterhouse House" (1884)
column2: and the "Maitland Art Center" (1937) . The area has always been a vacation spot because of its climate
column3: location to theme parks and people. Maitland has many picturesque parks along lakes

column1: The Maitland Center was established in 1982 adjacent to Interstate 4. Today its 226 acres (91 ha) include over 400 businesses and over 45 office buildings.Worldwide Brands has its headquarters in Maitland.Other local employers include:

The Maitland Public Library was instituted in 1896
column2: when Mrs. Clara J. Dommerich donated several hundred volumes of books from her personal library for the townspeople of Maitland to share. Originally housed in a citizen's home
column3: the collection was subsequently moved to a storefront near the railroad depot and then to its current home on South Maitland Avenue
column4: with renovations and expansions conducted in 1959
column6: and 1989. All expenditures were funded by donations until the City of Maitland took over the funding for the library in 1965
column9: Maitland government realized it could not use city tax money to build on the private property where the library stood. The Library's board turned over all assets
column11: the building and the entire collection
column13: the library building and operating budget is funded and its grounds and buildings maintained by the city. The library remains
column14: as it was in the beginning
column15: a non-profit corporation that is operated by city residents
column17: who are volunteers who meet monthly to participate in library business and decision-making. The library is a business and can still receive gifts and donations
column18: which contribute immensely to the Library's funding. The Friends of the Library are an active group that contribute time and monies to the library for books and supplies
column19: partly through their volunteer-run bookstore that is stocked by donations. Annual "Big Book Sales" are held by the Friends at the bookstore
